revision.text:
{{Infobox song contest entry | song = {{flagicon|Monaco}} "Boum-Badaboum" | image = | caption = | year = 1967 | country = Monaco | artist = Minouche Barelli | as = | with = | language = French | languages = | composer = [[Serge Gainsbourg]] | lyricist = [[Serge Gainsbourg]] | conductor = Aimé Barelli | place = 5th | points = 10 | lyrics = [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1967mc from Diggiloo Thrush] | prev = Bien plus fort | prev_link = Bien plus fort | next = À chacun sa chanson | next_link = À chacun sa chanson }} '''"Boum-Badaboum"''' was the [[Monaco|Monegasque]] entry in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1967]], performed in [[French language|French]] by [[Minouche Barelli]].
The song was composed by [[Serge Gainsbourg]], who previously had written [[France Gall]]'s winning entry "[[Poupée de cire, poupée de son]]" in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1965|1965]], representing [[Luxembourg]]. Gainsbourg would also go on to write [[Joëlle Ursull]]'s entry for France, "[[White and Black Blues]]", which finished 2nd in [[Eurovision Song Contest 1990|1990]].
"Boum Badadoum" is part of the long Eurovision tradition of nonsensical titles and lyrics. However, instead of the usual Eurovision cannons of love and happiness associated with the genre, Barelli instead asks to be allowed to live a full life before she is killed in a bomb attack. In this regard, the song could actually regarded as critical of the normal nonsensical "boom-boom" lyrics of Eurovision entries. The phrases ''"boum-badaboum"'' and ''"boum boum"'' and a countdown are repeated throughout the lyrics. Barelli recorded the song in four languages; French, [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]], and [[Italian language|Italian]] - all versions with the same title.
The song was performed fourteenth on the night, following [[Norway]]'s [[Kirsti Sparboe]] with "[[Dukkemann]]" and preceding [[Yugoslavia]]'s [[Lado Leskovar]] with "[[Vse rože sveta]]". At the close of voting, it had received 10 points, placing 5th in a field of 17.
It was succeeded as [[Monaco in the Eurovision Song Contest|Monegasque representative]] at the [[Eurovision Song Contest 1968|1968 Contest]] by [[Line & Willy]] with "[[À chacun sa chanson]]".
==Sources and external links== * [http://www.eurovision.tv/page/history/by-year/contest?event=284 Official Eurovision Song Contest site, history by year, 1967] * [http://www.diggiloo.net/?1967mc Detailed info and lyrics, The Diggiloo Thrush, "Boum-Badaboum".]

revision.text:
'''Council for a Livable World''' is a [[Washington, D.C.]]-based non-profit, advocacy organization dedicated to eliminating the [[Nuclear weapons and the United States|U.S. arsenal of nuclear weapons]]. Its stated aim is for "progressive national security policies and helping elect congressional candidates who support them."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://us.oneworld.net/contact/company/view/8726 |title=OneWorld: where the good guys gang up |publisher=Us.oneworld.net |date= |accessdate=2013-01-11}}</ref> The Council was founded in 1962 as the Council for Abolishing War by Hungarian nuclear physicist [[Leó Szilárd]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Hawkins, Helen S. / Greb, G. Allen / Szilard, Gertrud Weiss, Eds|title=Toward a Livable World: Leo Szilard and the Crusade for Nuclear Arms Control|year=1987|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=0-262-19260-8|url=http://alsos.wlu.edu/information.aspx?id=2809}}</ref> Its research arm, the [[Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation]], provides research to members of Congress and their staff. In February, 2016, [[John F. Tierney]] was appointed the executive director of the Council for a Livable World and the Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation,<ref>{{cite news|title=Former Congressman John Tierney named Executive Director of The Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation|url=http://armscontrolcenter.org/press-release-former-congressman-john-tierney-named-executive-director-of-the-center-for-arms-control-and-non-proliferation/|accessdate=21 September 2016|publisher=The Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation|date=24 February 2016}}</ref> the council’s affiliated education and research organization. For more than 50 years, the Council for a Livable World has been advocating for a more principled approach to U.S. national security and foreign policy.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Council for a Livable World|url=http://livableworld.org/about/|website=Council for a Livable World|publisher=Council for a Livable World}}</ref>
==Policy influence and lobbying== Every election cycle, the Council endorses congressional candidates who are arms control advocates and who support the Council's outlook on national security issues. Since its inception, the Council has helped elect 134 U.S. arms control advocates to the Senate and 226 to the House of Representatives. Council supporters raised over $1.6 million in 2014. Candidates seeking endorsements are required to answer questionnaires on issues and to defend their positions in interviews. The Council endorses candidates for the House of Representatives through PeacePAC. The Council endorsed both President [[Barack Obama]]<ref>{{cite news|author1=Broad, William J. |author2=Sanger, David E.|title=Obama's Youth Shaped His Nuclear-Free Vision|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/world/05nuclear.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 4, 2009}}</ref> and Vice President [[Joe Biden]]<ref>{{cite book|last=Witcover|first=Jules|title=Joe Biden: A Life of Trial and Redemption|year=2010|publisher=William Morrow|isbn=0061791989}}</ref> in their first runs for U.S. Senate seats.
The Council has influenced U.S. arms control and national security policies for over fifty years by working on or supporting several issues including:
* Rallying support on Capitol Hill in favor of the [[Iran nuclear deal]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Executive Director Angela Canterbury Urges Congress to Support the Iran Deal|url=http://livableworld.org/executive-director-angela-canterbury-urges-congress-to-support-the-iran-deal/|website=Council for a Livable World|publisher=Council for a Livable World|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> * Ratifying the [[Chemical Weapons Convention]]<ref>{{cite journal|title=20-year battle on chemical weapons is over|journal=[[The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists]]|date=July–August 1990|volume=46|issue=6}}</ref> and [[Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty]], Conventional Forces in Europe, [[START I|Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty]] (START)<ref>{{cite journal|title=START makes sense despite oversell|journal=The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists|date=June 1990|volume=46|issue=5}}</ref> and the [[New Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty]] (New START) <ref>{{cite news|author1=Megan Scully |author2=Dan Friedman |author3=Aamer Madhani |title=New START Shows Signs of Life in Senate|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/new-start-shows-signs-of-life-in-senate-20101220|newspaper=[[National Journal]]|date=December 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Grossman|first=Elaine|title=Treaty Battle May Presage Key GOP Senator's National Security Role|url=http://www.nti.org/gsn/article/treaty-battle-may-presage-key-gop-senators-national-security-role/|publisher=[[Nuclear Threat Initiative]]|work= Global Security Newswire|accessdate=December 23, 2010}}</ref> * Establishing a U.S. nuclear testing moratorium in 1992 * Banning biological weapons and terminating [[chemical weapons]] programs <ref>{{cite journal|title=Banning Chemical Weapons|journal=Technology Review|date=October 1990|volume=93|issue=7|pages=32–40}}</ref> * Limiting the deployment of the [[MX missile]] and [[B-2 bomber]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Isaacs|first=John|title=Second Invasion: Arms Salesmen Cash In|newspaper=[[St. Louis Post Dispatch]]|date=September 13, 1990}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Isaacs|first=John|title=Resist the Rush to Buy More Arms|newspaper=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|date=September 26, 1990}}</ref> * Blocking deployment of [[National Missile Defense]] by the [[Clinton administration]] * Eliminating funding for the nuclear "[[Bunker Buster]]" and "[[Reliable Replacement Warhead]]," two new generations of nuclear weapons
==Father Robert F. Drinan National Peace and Human Rights Award== [[File:Robert Drinan.jpg|thumb|In 1970, Father [[Robert Drinan]] became the first Roman Catholic priest to be elected to the United States Congress. He served five terms as a congressman before an edict by [[Pope John Paul II]] instructed all Catholic priests to withdraw from electoral politics.]] Since 2006, Council for a Livable World and its research center and sister organization, Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation, present the [[Father Robert F. Drinan]] National Peace and Human Rights Award to individuals who exemplify the late Father Drinan's commitment to peace and human justice.<ref>{{cite web|title=Father Robert F. Drinan National Peace and Human Rights Award|url=http://livableworld.org/what/father_robert_f_drinan_national_peace_and_human_rights_award/}}</ref> The award broadly focuses on U.S. politics, political science, physical science, biology, peace studies, and peace and human rights activism.
===Officers=== *Robert K. Musil, Chair, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board>{{cite web|title=Board|url=http://livableworld.org/about/board/|website=Council for a Livable World|accessdate=June 12, 2017}}</ref> *Jules Zacher, Vice-Chair, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Timothy L. Brennan, Secretary, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Lorin Walker, Treasurer, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/>
==Board of directors== *Aron Bernstein, Professor of Physics Emeritus, [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]], Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Paul Castleman, Business Executive, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Alice T. Day, Sociologist, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Laurie Dewey, Activist; Philanthropist, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Katherine Magraw, Foundation Consultant, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Gene Pokorny, Consultant, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Philip G. Schrag, Professor of Law, [[Georgetown University]], Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Dr. James Walsh, Research Associate, [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology’s Security Studies Program]] (SSP), Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Daniel Wirls, Professor, [[Merrill College]], [[University of California]], Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Lt. General [[Robert Gard]] (ret. USA) PhD, Chairman of the Board, Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation * Nicholas Clark, Business executive, and adjunct professor
==National advisory board== *Margaret Gage, President and Executive Director, Proteus Fund, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Sen. [[Gary Hart]], Former U.S. Senator, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Lawrence Hess, Businessman, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *John Isaacs, Senior Fellow, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *General John H. Johns, retired brigadier general, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Colonel Richard Klass, U.Ss Air Force (ret.), Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *Priscilla Johnson McMillan, Associate, Davis Center for Russian and Eurasian Studies, Harvard University, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *[[Matthew Meselson]], Professor, Natural Sciences, Harvard University, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/> *[[Richard Schiff]], Actor, Council for a Livable World<ref name=Board/>
==Staff== *The Honorable [[John F. Tierney|John Tierney]], Executive Director, Former Member of Congress (1997-2015) *John Isaacs, Senior Fellow, Council for a Livable World *Cain Farmer, Controller, Council for a Livable World *Hazel Correa, Communications Director, Council for a Livable World *Greg Terryn, Policy Analyst, Council for a Livable World *James McKeon, Policy Analyst, Council for a Livable World *Khalil Cutair, Staff Accountant, Council for a Livable World
==References==
<references/>
==External links== *[http://www.clw.org/ Council for a Livable World website] *[http://blog.livableworld.org/ Chain Reaction, the Council's blog] *[http://armscontrolcenter.org/ Center for Arms Control and Non-Proliferation website] The Council's research organization
{{DEFAULTSORT:Council For A Livable World}} [[Category:Anti–nuclear weapons movement]] [[Category:Peace organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1962]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist | name = Dawn Y. Sumner | image = Dawn Y Sumner in Pearse Valley, Antarctica.jpg | caption = Dawn Sumner in Pearse Valley, [[Dry Valleys]], Antarctica | birth_place = [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)]], USA | workplaces = [[University of California, Davis]] | alma_mater = [[Caltech]]; [[MIT]] | known_for = microbial life in extreme environments
ancient microbial life | awards = Fellow of the [[Geological Society of America]]
Career Award for Outstanding Contributions in Geosciences, Geobiology and Microbiology from the Geological Society of America | website = https://dysumner.faculty.ucdavis.edu/ }} '''Dawn Yvonne Sumner''' is an American [[geologist]], [[planetary scientist]], and [[astrobiologist]]. She is a professor at the [[University of California, Davis]]. Sumner’s research includes evaluating [[microbial communities]] in [[List of lakes#Antarctica|Antarctic lakes]], exploration of [[Mars]] via the [[Curiosity (rover)|Curiosity rover]], and characterization of microbial communities in the lab and from ancient geologic samples. She is an investigator on the [[Mars Science Laboratory|NASA Mars Science Laboratory]] (MSL) and was Chair of the UC Davis Department of Earth & Planetary Sciences{{Cite web|url=http://geology.ucdavis.edu/|title=Department of Geology, UC Davis|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} from 2014-2016.{{Cite web|url=https://geology.ucdavis.edu/sites/g/files/dgvnsk2851/files/inline-files/F15news_online.pdf|title=UC Davis Earth and Planetary Science department; Chair's letter by Dawn Sumner|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} She is Fellow of the [[Geological Society of America]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.geosociety.org/GSA/About/awards/GSA_Fellows/GSA/Awards/Fellowship.aspx|title=GSA Fellow|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} == Early life and education == Sumner was born near [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]], and spent part of her childhood on the [[Yakama Indian Reservation]] in the [[Pacific Northwest]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.newsreview.com/sacramento/mars-needs-this-woman/content?oid=17298240|title=Mars needs this woman|last=Leibrock|first=Rachel|date=6 April 2015|website=newsreview.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} From there, she earned a B.S. with Honors in geology from the [[California Institute of Technology]] (Caltech), then attended the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] for her Ph.D. which she completed in 1995. Sumner then returned Caltech for postdoctoral research, supported by an O.K. Earl Postdoctoral Fellowship.{{Cite news|url=http://gradfund.rutgers.edu/blog/awards/6216/|title=California Institute of Technology: The O.K. Earl Postdoctoral Fellowship and the Texaco Postdoctoral Fellowship - GradFund|work=GradFund|access-date=2018-10-03|language=en-US}} == Career == *Ancient Microbial Communities - Sumner’s research includes understanding microbial evolution and ecology, and Earth history,  through understanding microbial signatures in the rock record. Her publications feature new developments in how to interpret ancient biological responses to environmental factors, tracing oxygenation{{Cite journal|last=Sumner|first=Dawn Y.|last2=Grotzinger|first2=John P.|date=1996|title=Were kinetics of Archean calcium carbonate precipitation related to oxygen concentration?|url=https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/gsa/geology/article-abstract/24/2/119/206445|journal=Geology|language=en|volume=24|issue=2|pages=119|doi=10.1130/0091-7613(1996)024<0119:WKOACC>2.3.CO;2|issn=0091-7613}} and the impact on carbonate microbial biological signatures.{{Cite journal|last=Sumner|first=Dawn Y.|date=1997-05-01|title=Carbonate precipitation and oxygen stratification in late Archean seawater as deduced from facies and stratigraphy of the Gamohaan and Frisco formations, Transvaal Supergroup, South Africa|url=http://www.ajsonline.org/content/297/5/455|journal=American Journal of Science|language=en|volume=297|issue=5|pages=455–487|doi=10.2475/ajs.297.5.455|issn=0002-9599}} *Antarctic Lakes Sumner’s research utilizes Antarctic lakes as a model system for understanding microbial processes, early oxygenic photosynthesis, and life on other planets. This work includes the discovery of pinnacles of microbial growth under ice-covered lakes{{Cite journal|last=Sumner|first=D. Y.|last2=Jungblut|first2=A. D.|last3=Hawes|first3=I.|last4=Andersen|first4=D. T.|last5=Mackey|first5=T. J.|last6=Wall|first6=K.|date=2016-07-29|title=Growth of elaborate microbial pinnacles in Lake Vanda, Antarctica|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/gbi.12188|journal=Geobiology|language=en|volume=14|issue=6|pages=556–574|doi=10.1111/gbi.12188|issn=1472-4677}} and describes multiple microbial communities involved in the development of these features.  Similar features in another Antarctic lake appear to record changes in the lake environment, including sea level, through time.{{Cite journal|last=Mackey|first=T. J.|last2=Sumner|first2=D. Y.|last3=Hawes|first3=I.|last4=Leidman|first4=S. Z.|last5=Andersen|first5=D. T.|last6=Jungblut|first6=A. D.|date=2017-11-24|title=Stromatolite records of environmental change in perennially ice-covered Lake Joyce, McMurdo Dry Valleys, Antarctica|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10533-017-0402-1|journal=Biogeochemistry|language=en|volume=137|issue=1-2|pages=73–92|doi=10.1007/s10533-017-0402-1|issn=0168-2563}} *Exploration of Mars and its Environments Professor Sumner’s research with the Mars Science Laboratory has generated over three dozen collaborative publications. Sumner’s research has established that parts of ancient Mars could have hosted life as we know it on Earth,{{Cite journal|last=Grotzinger|first=J. P.|last2=Sumner|first2=D. Y.|last3=Kah|first3=L. C.|last4=Stack|first4=K.|last5=Gupta|first5=S.|last6=Edgar|first6=L.|last7=Rubin|first7=D.|last8=Lewis|first8=K.|last9=Schieber|first9=J.|date=2013-12-09|title=A Habitable Fluvio-Lacustrine Environment at Yellowknife Bay, Gale Crater, Mars|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/early/2013/12/05/science.1242777|journal=Science|language=en|pages=1242777|doi=10.1126/science.1242777|issn=0036-8075|pmid=24324272}} and contributed to the discovery of organic molecules on Mars.{{Cite journal|last=Eigenbrode|first=Jennifer L.|last2=Summons|first2=Roger E.|last3=Steele|first3=Andrew|last4=Freissinet|first4=Caroline|last5=Millan|first5=Maëva|last6=Navarro-González|first6=Rafael|last7=Sutter|first7=Brad|last8=McAdam|first8=Amy C.|last9=Franz|first9=Heather B.|last10=Glavin|first10=Daniel P.|last11=Archer Jr.|first11=Paul D.|last12=Mahaffy|first12=Paul R.|last13=Conrad|first13=Pamela G.|last14=Hurowitz|first14=Joel A.|last15=Grotzinger|first15=John P.|last16=Gupta|first16=Sanjeev|last17=Ming|first17=Doug W.|last18=Sumner|first18=Dawn Y.|last19=Szopa|first19=Cyril|last20=Malespin|first20=Charles|last21=Buch|first21=Arnaud|last22=Coll|first22=Patrice|date=2018-06-08|title=Organic matter preserved in 3-billion-year-old mudstones at Gale crater, Mars|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/360/6393/1096|journal=Science|language=en|volume=360|issue=6393|pages=1096–1101|doi=10.1126/science.aas9185|issn=0036-8075|pmid=29880683}} Sumner is a MSL “long term planner”,{{Cite news|url=https://www.davisenterprise.com/local-news/ucd/uc-davis-scientist-prepares-for-mars-rover-landing/|title=UC Davis scientist prepares for Mars rover landing|date=2012-08-04|work=Davis Enterprise|access-date=2018-10-09|language=en-US}} one of several lead geoscientists amongst more than five hundred scientists not directly employed by [[NASA]] on this project. She is also involved in future planning for additional Mars exploration, [[Mars 2020|including a mission in 2020]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.nature.com/news/nasa-plans-mars-sample-return-rover-1.15207|title=NASA plans mars sample-return rover|last=Witze|first=Alexandra|date=May 5, 2014|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 16, 2018}} == Awards and honors == Sumner was elected a Fellow of the Geological Society of America in 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://www.geosociety.org/GSA/About/awards/GSA_Fellows/GSA/Awards/Fellows.aspx#S|title=Dawn Sumner GSA Fellow|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} Also in 2014, she was selected to deliver the honorary Carl Sagan Lecture at the [[American Geophysical Union]].{{Cite web|url=https://honors.agu.org/sfg-award-lecture/carl-sagan-lecture/|title=AGU Honors; Carl Sagan Lecture; Past Recipients; Dawn Sumner|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} In 2016, Sumner was awarded the Career Award for Outstanding Contributions in Geosciences, Geobiology and Microbiology from the Geological Society of America.{{Cite web|url=http://gsageobiology.blogspot.com/2016/09/2016-division-awards.html|title=GSA Geobiology and Geomicrobiology: 2016 Division Awards for outstanding research|last=Martindale|first=Rowan|date=2016-09-19|website=GSA Geobiology and Geomicrobiology|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-04}} == Gender equity and sexual harassment in science == Sumner is the author of a widely used anti-harassment statement that she made public so that other universities and institutes could use it as a model.{{Cite web|url=https://dysumner.faculty.ucdavis.edu/sexual-harassment-statement-for-my-department/|title=Sumner white paper on anti-harassment|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} A leader in helping institutions develop anti-harassment plans, Sumner presented to a workshop at the 2016 [[American Geophysical Union]] on “Addressing harassment and improving workplace climate.”{{Cite web|url=https://serc.carleton.edu/departments/heads-chairs16/index.html|title=Sumner presentation at AGU to department head and chairs on harassment|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} She was also an invited presenter for [[Association of Polar Early Career Scientists]] webinar on sexual harassment during fieldwork.{{Cite web|url=https://www.apecs.is/career-resources/webinars/webinar-archive/details/10/165.html|title=Sumner presentation to polar scientists on harassment during fieldwork|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} == Selected publications == * ''Were kinetics of Archean calcium carbonate precipitation related to oxygen concentration?'' Geology, v. 24, p. 119-122. DOI: [https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/gsa/geology/article-abstract/24/2/119/206445/were-kinetics-of-archean-calcium-carbonate?redirectedFrom=fulltext 10.1130/0091-7613] Sumner, Dawn Y. and John P. Grotzinger, 1996. * ''Late Archean calcite-microbe interactions: Two morphologically distinct microbial communities that affected calcite nucleation differently.'' Palaios, v. 12, p. 300-316. DOI: [https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/sepm/palaios/article-abstract/12/4/302/99654/late-archean-calcite-microbe-interactions-two?redirectedFrom=fulltext 10.2307/3515333], Sumner, Dawn Y., 1997. * ''[https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/books/book/1880/chapter/11530605/late-archean-aragonite-precipitationpetrography Late Archean aragonite precipitation: Petrography, facies associations, and environmental significance],'' ''in'' ''Carbonate Sedimentation and Diagenesis in the Evolving Precambrian World'', J. Grotzinger and N. James, editors, S.E.P.M. Special Publication #67, p. 123-144. Sumner, Dawn Y. and John P. Grotzinger, 2000. * ''Renalcids as fossilized biofilm clusters''. Palaios, v. 17, p. 225-236. DOI:[https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/sepm/palaios/article-abstract/17/3/225/99840/renalcids-as-fossilized-biofilm-clusters?redirectedFrom=fulltext 10.1669/0883-1351(2002)017<0225:RAFBC>2.0.CO;2], Stephens, Nat P. and Sumner, Dawn Y., 2002. * ''Poor preservational potential of organics in Meridiani Planum hematite-bearing sedimentary rocks'', Journal of Geophysical Research, Planets, v. 109, E12007. DOI:[https://agupubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1029/2004JE002321 10.1029/2004JE002321]. Sumner, Dawn Y., 2004. * ''Cracks and fins in sulfate sand: Evidence for recent mineral-atmospheric water cycling in Meridiani Planum outcrops?'' Geology, v. 34, p. 229-232. DOI: [https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/gsa/geology/article-abstract/34/4/229/129491/cracks-and-fins-in-sulfate-sand-evidence-for?redirectedFrom=fulltext 10.1130/G22101.1]. Chavdarian, Gregory V., and Sumner, Dawn Y. 2006. * ''Isotopic fingerprints of microbial respiration in aragonite from Bahamian stromatolites.'' Geology, v. 34, p. 973-976. DOI [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/249521319_Isotopic_fingerprints_of_microbial_respiration_in_aragonite_from_Bahamian_stromatolites 10.1130/G22859A.1]. Andres., Dawn Y. Sumner, et al. 2006. * ''Undirected motility of filamentous cyanobacteria produces reticulate mats.'' Geobiology, v. 8, p. 179-190. DOI: [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20345889 10.1111/j.1472-4669.2010.00235.x] Shepard, Rebekah N., and Sumner, Dawn Y., 2010. * ''Discovery of large conical stromatolites in Lake Untersee, Antarctica.'' Geobiology, v.9. 280–293. DOI: [https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1472-4669.2011.00279.x 10.1111/j.1472-4669.2011.00279.x.] Andersen, Dale T., Sumner, Dawn Y., et al., 2011. * ''Origins of Microbial Microstructures In the Neoproterozoic Beck Spring Dolomite: Variations In Microbial Community and Timing of Lithification.'' Journal of Sedimentary Research, v. 82, p. 709-722, DOI: [https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/sepm/jsedres/article-abstract/82/9/709/258312/origins-of-microbial-microstructures-in-the 10.2110/jsr.2012.65]. Harwood, Cara L., and Sumner, Dawn Y., 2012. * ''Antarctic microbial mats: A modern analog for Archean lacustrine oxygen oases.'' Geology, v. 43, p. 887-890. DOI: [https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/gsa/geology/article-abstract/43/10/887/131714/antarctic-microbial-mats-a-modern-analog-for?redirectedFrom=fulltext 10.1130/G36966.1]. Sumner, Dawn Y., Hawes, Ian, et al., 2015. * ''Growth of elaborate microbial pinnacles in Lake Vanda, Antarctica.'' Geobiology, v. 14, p. 556-574. DOI: [https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/gbi.12188 10.1111/gbi.12188]. Sumner, Dawn Y., Anne D. Jungblut, et al., 2016. * ''A habitable fluvio-lacustrine environment at Yellowknife Bay, Gale Crater, Mars.'' Science, v. 343, 1242777. DOI: [http://science.sciencemag.org/content/343/6169/1242777 10.1126/science.1242777], Grotzinger, J.P., D.Y. Sumner, et al., 2014 (online 2013). == Outreach == Sumner has presented lectures to public and school groups, and she has participated in videos and films on exploring Mars.  These have included presentations at [[Sierra College]],{{Cite news|url=http://www.placerherald.com/article/10/14/15/nasa-scientist-discuss-mars-rocklin-event|title=NASA scientist to discuss Mars at Rocklin event|work=Rocklin's Placer Herald|access-date=2018-10-08|language=en}} a Northern California [[Rotary International|Rotary Club]],{{Cite news|url=https://portal.clubrunner.ca/3544/stories/your-weekly-get-up-go-has-been-updated-15|title=Your Weekly Get Up & Go has been Updated!|work=Davis Sunrise Rotary Club|access-date=2018-10-09}} and [[California State University, Sacramento|Sacramento State University’s]] Science in the River City.{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/events/sirc-science-in-the-river-city-november-2017/451899458503039/|title=Science in River City|last=|first=|date=November 14, 2017|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} She appeared in several videos on Mars exploration, including ones hosted by UC Davis{{Citation|last=University of California|title=The Rover Curiosity|date=2013-02-26|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ncZc65EaFL8&t=4s|access-date=2018-10-09}} and in the Finnish documentary film “The Other Side of Mars”.{{Cite web|url=http://catalogue.ses.fi/movies/the-other-side-of-mars/|title=The Other Side of Mars {{!}} Finnish Film Catalogue 2018|website=catalogue.ses.fi|language=en|access-date=2018-10-09}} Dawn Sumner’s research has been covered in local and national media outlets, including [[Popular Science]],{{Cite web|url=https://www.popsci.com/organic-matter-rocks-on-mars|title=Is there life on Mars? TBD. But scientists found ancient organic matter in the Red Planet’s rocks.|last=Griggs|first=Mary Beth|date=June 7, 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=October 12, 2018}} [[Wired (magazine)|Wired Magazine]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.wired.com/2011/04/antarctica-lake-untersee/|title=Antarctic Lake Hides Bizarre Ecosystem|last=Witze|first=Alexandra|date=April 14, 2011|work=WIRED|access-date=2018-10-04|language=en-US}} [[KPCC]] public radio,{{Cite news|url=https://www.scpr.org/programs/take-two/2013/10/10/34109/shutdown-puts-scientists-antarctica-research-on-ic/|title=Shutdown puts scientists' Antarctica research on ice|last=Radio|first=Southern California Public|date=2013-10-10|work=Southern California Public Radio|access-date=2018-10-04}} the television series [[TakePart|Take Part]],{{Cite news|url=http://www.takepart.com/article/2015/05/18/girls-with-toys-hashtag-challenges-idea-science-playground-guys/|title='Girls With Toys’ Hashtag Challenges Idea That Science Is a Playground for Guys|work=TakePart|access-date=2018-10-04|language=en}} and the [[BBC]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/av/science-environment-19111453/mars-curiosity-rover-s-powerful-lab-kit|title=Mars rover’s powerful lab kit|last=|first=|date=August 3, 2012|website=BBC News|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-04}} == See also == * [[Extremophile|Extremophiles]] *[[Astrobiology]] *[[Paleobiology]] *[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] *[[John P. Grotzinger|John Grotzinger]] *[[Lake Untersee]] *[[Lake Vanda]] *[[Gale (crater)|Gale Crater]] == References == == External links == * [https://phylogenomics.me/2012/08/03/ucdavis-prof-dawn-sumner-video-interview-on-being-involved-in-mars-curiosity-rover-landing/ Sumner video interview on Curiosity rover] *[https://fri.ucdavis.edu/people/dawn-sumner Sumner profile at UC Davis] *[http://dawninantarctica.blogspot.com/ Sumner Antarctic blog] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sumner, Dawn}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:American geologists]] [[Category:American women geologists]] [[Category:Women Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:University of California, Davis faculty]]

{{Other uses|Federal Gazette (disambiguation)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Use British English|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = {{lang-de|Bundesblatt}}
{{lang-fr|Feuille fédérale}}
{{lang-it|Foglio federale}} | school = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | image = Swiss Copyright Law of 1883.pdf | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = The ''Bundesblatt'' on 7 July 1883. | motto = | type = Weekly [[Government gazette|official journal]] | format = | owner = | founder = | publisher = [[Federal Chancellery of Switzerland]] | president = | editor = | chiefeditor = | depeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | generalmanager = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | dirinteractive = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | metroeditor = | metrochief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = {{start date and age|1849}} | political = | language = German
French
Italian | ceased publication = | relaunched = | headquarters = | publishing_city = | publishing_country = | circulation = | circulation_date = | circulation_ref = | readership = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | RNI = | website = [https://www.admin.ch/gov/de/start/bundesrecht/bundesblatt.html www.admin.ch] | free = }} The '''''Federal Gazette''''' ({{lang-de|Bundesblatt}}, BBl; {{lang-fr|Feuille fédérale}}, FF; {{lang-it|Foglio federale}}, FF) publishes various official texts of the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] federal government, including: * reports of the [[Swiss Federal Council]] to the [[Swiss Federal Assembly]], most notably the drafts of proposed laws with usually extensive explanations, * laws enacted by Parliament that are subject to an obligatory or facultative [[popular referendum]], * reports and notifications by the Federal Council, parliamentary committees and various government agencies. It is issued in the [[Languages of Switzerland|three official languages of Switzerland]]: German, French and [[Italian language|Italian]]. All three language editions are equally valid. It is published by the [[Federal Chancellery of Switzerland]] in the form of weekly supplements to [[loose leaf]] binders. Since 1999, they are also made available on the internet in [[PDF]] format. Since 1 January 2016, the electronic version (and not any more the printed one) of the ''Official Compilation'' and of the ''Federal Gazette'' is deemed authentic. == See also == * [[Law of Switzerland]] * ''[[Official Compilation of Federal Legislation]]'' * ''[[Systematic Compilation of Federal Legislation]]'' * ''[[Federal Register]]'' * ''[[Official Journal of the European Union]]'' == References == {{refbegin}} * {{cite swiss law | sr = 170.512 | link = 170_512 | art = | date = 2004-06-18 | en = Federal Publications Law | enab = | de = | deab = | fr = | frab = | it = | itab = }} * {{cite web|title=Schweizerische Bundeskanzlei - Publikationsrecht|language=German|author=[[Federal Chancellery of Switzerland]]|url=http://www.bk.admin.ch/themen/gesetz/00051/index.html?lang=de}} * {{cite web |title=Introduction to the Swiss Legal System: A Guide for Foreign Researchers |first=Fridolin M. R. |last=Walther |publisher=Law Library Resource Xchange |date=15 November 2001 |accessdate=20 June 2014 |oclc=753910374 |url=http://www.llrx.com/features/swiss2.htm |ref={{harvid|LLRX|2001}} |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131011101504/http://www.llrx.com/features/swiss2.htm |archivedate=11 October 2013 |df=dmy }} * {{cite book|title=Directory of legal gazettes in Europe|year=2008|page=60|author=European Forum of Official Gazettes|publisher=[[Office for Official Publications of the European Communities]]|isbn=978-92-78-40518-2|url=https://circabc.europa.eu/webdav/CircaBC/OPOCE/ojf/Information/prod/data/pdf/directory2008.pdf}} {{refend}} == External links == * {{de icon}} [http://www.admin.ch/bundesrecht/00568/index.html?lang=de Bundesblatt] * {{fr icon}} [http://www.admin.ch/bundesrecht/00568/index.html?lang=fr Feuille fédérale] * {{it icon}} [http://www.admin.ch/bundesrecht/00568/index.html?lang=it Foglio federale] {{Portal bar|Switzerland|Law}} [[Category:Swiss law]] [[Category:Government gazettes|Switzerland Federal Journal]] {{law-book-stub}} {{Switzerland-stub}}

{{Infobox organization | name = Federation of Chiropractic Licensing Boards | image = | image_size = | caption = | logo = Federation_of_Chiropractic_Licensing_Boards_logo.jpg | logo_size = 160 | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | abbreviation = FCLB | motto = | predecessor = International Congress of Chiropractic Examining Boards | merged = | successor = | formation = 1926 (ICCEB)
1974 (FCLB) | purpose = Non-profit advisory board | headquarters = [[Greeley, Colorado]] | location = 5401 W. 10th Street
Suite 101 | coords = {{coord|40.421680|-104.771243|display=inline, title}} | region = | membership = | membership_year = | leader_title = President | leader_name = Maggie Colucci | affiliations = [[National Board of Chiropractic Examiners|NBCE]], [[Council on Chiropractic Education|CCE]] | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = $900,529{{cite web|title=Federation of Chiropractic Licensing Boards (A Not-For-Profit Corporation) Financial Report|url=http://www.fclb.org/Portals/7/Financial%20Reports/2016Annual%20Audit%20Report.pdf|website=FCLB|accessdate=20 October 2017}} | revenue_year = 2016 | disbursements = | expenses = $695,872 | expenses_year = 2016 | endowment = | endowment_year = | staff = | staff_year = | website = {{URL|http://www.fclb.org/}} }} The '''Federation of Chiropractic Licensing Boards''', based in [[Greeley, Colorado]], is a non-profit organization which facilitates the coordination and communication of the 50 individual United States' chiropractic licensing boards.{{cite book|last1=Cherkin|first1=Daniel C|last2=Mootz|first2=Robert D|title=Chiropractic in the United States: Training, Practice, and Research|date=December 1997|publisher=AHCPR Publication|pages=34–36|accessdate=20 October 2017}}{{cite book|last=Faass|first=Nancy|title=Integrating Complementary Medicine Into Health Systems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yTx6kPjXt3EC&pg=PA562|year=2001|publisher=Jones & Bartlett Learning|isbn=978-0-8342-1216-9|page=562}} ==History== The earliest ancestor of the FCLB was chartered in [[Memphis, Tennessee|Memphis]] in September 1926 as the International Congress of Chiropractic Examining Boards.{{cite book|last1=Peterson|first1=Dennis|last2=Wiese|first2=Glenda|title=Chiropractic: An Illustrated History|date=1995|publisher=Mosby|isbn=978-0801677359|page=203}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fclb.org/AboutFCLB.aspx|title=FCLB|first=FCLB Home|last=Website|publisher=}} From this organization, Congress created the Council of State Chiropractic Examining Boards (CSCEB) in 1933. This board was originally associated with the [[American Chiropractic Association|National Chiropractic Association]], but by 1947 decided to withdraw itself from the influence of any national association and formed its own independently-run organization. Incorporating itself in Wyoming it received federal tax-exempt status in 1968. By 1974 the name of the organization was changed to its present-day name, the Federation of Chiropractic Licensing Boards.{{cite web |last= Keating |first= Joseph Jr |title= Milestones in the history of Chiropractic |url= http://www.chiroweb.com/mpacms/dc_ca/article.php?id=51278 |publisher= Dynamic Chiropractic |website= Chiroweb.com}} The newly formed FCLB first sought to arbitrate the merger of the [[Association of Chiropractic Colleges]] with the [[Council on Chiropractic Education – USA|Council on Chiropractic Education]] (CCE) as both were attempting to earn national accreditation from the [[United States Department of Education|United States Office of Education]]. As arbitration drew near the CCE secured accreditation from the U.S. government, and quickly thereafter the FCLB supported its claim on the government petition. ==Mission== The mission of the FCLB is to maintain high, uniform standards in areas related to [[chiropractic]] licensure, regulation, discipline, and education. The organization provides services to member chiropractic licensing boards to fulfill their statutory obligations and regulate the profession within the interest of public protection.{{cite web|url=http://www.fclb.org/AboutFCLB/ArticlesofIncorporation.aspx|title=Articles of Incorporation|first=FCLB Home|last=Website|publisher=}}{{cite book |author= United States. Department of Health and Human Services. Office of Inspector General. Office of Analysis and Inspections, and Richard P. Kusserow |title= State Licensure and Discipline of Chiropractors |publisher= The Office |date= 1989 |url= https://www.chirobase.org/19Insurance/oig/1989.pdf |via= [https://www.chirobase.org Chirobase] |pages= 25–6, 31, 40}} ==Affiliations== The Federation of Chiropractic Licensing Boards collaborates closely with the [[National Board of Chiropractic Examiners]] (NBCE) and [[Council on Chiropractic Education]] (CCE) because of their shared mission of public protection. The FCLB also works closely with the NBCE and to develop uniform standards of education and examination for its national board exams parts 1-4.{{cite journal |last1= Eisenberg |first1= DM |last2= Cohen |first2= MH |last3= Hrbek |first3= A |last4= Grayzel |first4= J |last5= Van Rompay |first5= MI |last6= Cooper |first6= RA |display-authors= 2| title = Credentialing complementary and alternative medical providers | journal = [[Annals of Internal Medicine]] | volume = 137 | issue = 12 | pages = 965–73 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12484712 | doi = 10.7326/0003-4819-137-12-200212170-00010 | url = http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.692.9014&rep=rep1&type=pdf}} A database of providers called CIN-BAD (Chiropractic Information Network - Board Action Database) provides member boards and other subscribers access to information regarding licensed chiropractors in the US, Canada, and Australia. CIN-BAD's ever-expanding databases are increasingly significant resources for regulatory boards, chiropractic colleges, managed care providers, law enforcement agencies, and the public.{{cite news|title=Computer System Will Allow Licensing Boards to Network Information|url=http://www.dynamicchiropractic.com/mpacms/dc/article.php?id=42328|accessdate=20 October 2017|issue=Vol. 11, Issue 12|publisher=Dynamic Chiropractic|date=June 4, 1993}} A service called PACE (Providers of Approved Chiropractic Education) assists the member regulatory boards in validating quality educational courses for licensed chiropractors as well as tracking obtained continuing education credit hours for compliance purposes.{{cite news|last1=Engebretson|first1=Julie|title=FCLB Officially Launches PACE Program|url=http://www.dynamicchiropractic.com/mpacms/dc/article.php?id=51083|accessdate=20 October 2017|issue=Vol. 24, Issue 05|publisher=Dynamic Chiropractic|date=February 27, 2006}} The FCLB also manages a program for Certified Chiropractic Clinical Assistants, which is a certification program for competent office assistants who may legally provide certain limited clinical services in a chiropractic setting. The program establishes minimal testing, training and character standards for chiropractic assistants to best protect the public.{{cite news|last1=Schmitt|first1=Richard|title=National Certification for Chiropractic Assistants|url=http://www.dynamicchiropractic.com/mpacms/dc/article.php?id=55975|accessdate=20 October 2017|issue=Vol. 30, Issue 14|publisher=Dynamic Chiropractic|date=July 1, 2012}} ==Membership== Members include boards having jurisdiction to license or regulate the practice of chiropractic in the states, provinces, commonwealths, and territories of the United States of America, Australia, Canada, England, Mexico, New Zealand and other jurisdictions. Current regulatory board members, as well as those who have served on a board within the last five years, may participate as Fellows in FCLB activities, including holding office or serving on standing committees. Those who have ever served on a chiropractic regulatory board are Honorary Fellows, privileged to attend the annual business meeting. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.fclb.org/ FCLB website] *[http://www.nbce.org/ NBCE website] *[http://www.cce-usa.org/ Council on Chiropractic Education - USA (CCE-USA)] *http://www.cceb.ca/ CCEB website - Canada {{Chiropractic}} [[Category:Chiropractic organizations]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in Colorado]] [[Category:International medical and health organizations]]

[[File:GBIF network as of 29 Aug 2017.png|thumb|right|The formal members or 'Participants' in GBIF consist of countries, economies and international organizations that collaborate to advance free and open access to biodiversity data. This map displays GBIF’s national Participants as of 29 August 2017.]]
The '''Global Biodiversity Information Facility''' ('''GBIF''') is an [[international organisation]] that focuses on making scientific data on [[biodiversity]] available via the [[Internet]] using [[web services]]. The data are provided by many institutions from around the world; GBIF's information architecture makes these data accessible and searchable through a single portal. Data available through the GBIF portal are primarily distribution data on plants, animals, fungi, and microbes for the world, and scientific names data.
The mission of the Global Biodiversity information Facility (GBIF) is to facilitate free and open access to biodiversity data worldwide to underpin [[sustainable development]]. Priorities, with an emphasis on promoting participation and working through partners, include mobilising biodiversity data, developing protocols and standards to ensure scientific integrity and interoperability, building an informatics architecture to allow the interlinking of diverse data types from disparate sources, promoting capacity building and catalysing development of analytical tools for improved decision-making.
GBIF strives to form informatics linkages among digital data resources from across the spectrum of biological organisation, from genes to [[ecosystem]]s, and to connect these to issues important to science, society and sustainability by using georeferencing and [[Geographic information system|GIS]] tools. It works in partnership with other international organisations such as the [[Catalogue of Life]] partnership, [[Biodiversity Information Standards]], the [[Consortium for the Barcode of Life]] (CBOL), the [[Encyclopedia of Life]] (EOL), and [[GEOSS]].
== See also == * [[ABCD Schema]] * [[Atlas of Living Australia]] (ALA) * [[Australasian Virtual Herbarium]] (AVH) * [[Darwin Core]] * [[Global biodiversity]]
== External links == {{commons category|Images from GBIF}} * [https://www.gbif.org/ GBIF website] * [https://www.gbif.org/what-is-gbif Short description of GBIF] * [https://www.gbif.org/the-gbif-network GBIF network] * [https://www.gbif.org/publisher/search GBIF Data publishers]
[[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Biodiversity]] [[Category:Ecology organizations]] [[Category:Biodiversity databases]] [[Category:Online databases]] [[Category:International organizations based in Denmark]] {{int-org-stub}}

'''Greater Budapest''' is the name of [[Budapest]] in its present, extended size, as it was created by the ''Law No. XXVI of 1949'' passed on December 15, 1949 and it came into force on January 1, 1950. By attaching 7 towns and 16 villages to the former Budapest, its area enlarged from 207 km² to 525 km² (154%), the number of its inhabitants increased from 1.05 million to 1.6 million (52%), and the number of the districts augmented from 14 to 22 (57%), thus becoming the seventh metropolis of Europe in its time.
The only difference between the 1950s Greater Budapest and {{As of|2008|alt=today's}} Budapest is that [[List of districts in Budapest|Soroksár]], a part of District 20, voted for its independence in 1992, and in 1994 it became a separate District 23. The total area of Budapest remained the same.
In 1950, Inner Budapest (former [[Budapest|Little Budapest]]) had 1.05 million inhabitants and the annexed suburbs 0.55 million. Now Inner Budapest has only 0.95 million inhabitants while the former suburb's population increased to 0.75 million. In the 1960s neighbouring villages became the new suburbs (second suburban belt) with rapidly increasing population (from 1950 to 2009 these former villages and small towns population increased from 300,000 to nearly 800,000). Suburbanization and motorization generated traffic jams on urban multi-lane highways. 1 million cars run in Budapest on a weekday.
== See also == {{see also|Budapest metropolitan area}}
==References== [http://www.historia.hu/archivum/2000/000506siposa.htm Andás Sipos: Formation of Greater Budapest (Hungarian)]
[[Category:Demographics of Budapest]] [[Category:History of Budapest]] [[Category:1949 in Europe]]
{{hungary-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Gypsy Magic | image = | caption = | director = [[Stole Popov]] | producer = | writer = [[Vladimir Blazevski]] | starring = [[Bekir Adnan]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = {{Film date|1997}} | runtime = 126 minutes | country = Macedonia | language = Macedonian | budget = }} '''''Gypsy Magic''''' is a 1997 Macedonian film directed by [[Stole Popov]]. It was Macedonia's submission to the [[70th Academy Awards]] for the [[Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]], but was not accepted as a nominee.{{cite web|url=http://www.oscarguy.com/Oscars/Annual/70th/Foreign.html|title=The 70th Academy Awards (1997): Foreign Language Film Submissions|publisher=oscarguy.com|accessdate=2008-07-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080703172038/http://www.oscarguy.com/Oscars/Annual/70th/Foreign.html|archivedate=3 July 2008|df=dmy-all}}
- Margaret Herrick Library, Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
- {{cite web |title=44 Countries Hoping for Oscar Nominations |publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] |date=24 November 1997 |url=//www.oscars.org/pressreleases/97.11.24.html |accessdate=13 October 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19980213090309/http://www.oscars.org/pressreleases/97.11.24.html |archivedate=13 February 1998 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} ==Plot== A romantic story in gypsy family makes a last, desperate effort to find its way out of the Balkan absurdity and misfortune. Their story mirrors the universal story of the rejected and the maladjusted, the forgotten street heroes who make the news only in the obituaries or crime sections...
A romantic story about a gypsy family, living on the periphery of the Macedonian capital. It talks about their efforts through everyday life, colorfully describing their ambitions and their honest and sweet dreams (for the modern world maybe seemingly ridiculous). It is a film about the warm and always hopeful gypsy spirit and performing actual gypsy magic curses. Even though the story is placed in a rural area, it is an everywhere story, with everywhere problems and situations, some of it from every level of society. Big dreams, love, family, acceptance of diversity – are spices of this honest and touching story, which gone make you laugh, and cry, from time to time. A bed is an object of a big dream, does it's gone release?{{clarify|date=August 2012}} Someone dream is to be what is.{{clarify|date=August 2012}} Their dreams are maybe usual and boring but painfully honest.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}} ==See also== * [[List of submissions to the 70th Academy Awards for Best Foreign Language Film]] * [[List of Macedonian submissions for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0130752|title=Gypsy Magic}} [[Category:1997 films]] [[Category:Macedonian films]] [[Category:1990s comedy-drama films]] [[Category:Macedonian-language films]] [[Category:Romani-language films]] {{Macedonia-film-stub}} {{1990s-comedy-drama-film-stub}}

The '''International Festivals of the Sea''' are a series of maritime festivals, which have been held in various [[United Kingdom|British]] port cities since 1996. The festivals are intended to be celebrations of the sea, bringing together sailors, musicians, artists, entertainers, ships and boats from all points of the compass.
==History== The first International Festival of the Sea took place in [[Bristol]] in 1996, and the key theme was [[John Cabot]]'s pioneering voyage of discovery to the [[Americas]]. As part of the festival, a replica of Cabot's ship, the ''[[Matthew (ship)|Matthew]]'', was dedicated prior to its reenactment of Cabot's voyage the following year.
The relative success of the first festival, taken with the declining numbers of visitors to [[Navy Day]]s, encouraged the [[Royal Navy]] to invite the festival to [[Portsmouth]] in 1998 and 2001. Unlike the Bristol event, the Portsmouth events had a strong [[navy|naval]] component, and effectively combined the maritime heritage aspects of the first festival with the naval public relations aspects of the old Navy Days. Both events were highly successful with over 200,000 visitors to each.
The 2003 festival was held in [[Edinburgh]]'s port district of [[Leith]]. The 2005 International Festival of the Sea returned to Portsmouth as part of the [[Trafalgar 200]] and Sea Britain 2005 festivities to mark the 200th Anniversary of the [[Battle of Trafalgar]].
The 2005 Festival of the Sea was sadly the last major event of its type, however, the 2017 Poole Maritime Festival in conjunction with European Maritime Day is set to revive the tradition of popular maritime festivals on 18th to 21st May 2017.
==List of festivals== * [[International Festival of the Sea, 1996]] - [[Bristol]] * [[International Festival of the Sea, 1998]] - [[Portsmouth]] * [[International Festival of the Sea, 2001]] - [[Portsmouth]] * [[International Festival of the Sea, 2003]] - [[Leith]], [[Edinburgh]] * [[International Festival of the Sea, 2005]] - [[Portsmouth]]
[[Category:Festivals in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Maritime culture]]
{{UK-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} '''Khonvoum''' is the supreme god and creator of the [[Mbuti|Bambuti]] [[Pygmy]] people in [[central Africa]]. He is the 'great hunter', god of the hunt, and carries a bow made of two snakes which appears to mortals as a rainbow. He rules the heavens and when the sun sets, he gathers pieces of the stars and throws it at the sun so that it may rise the next day in its full splendor. He contacts people by means of the mythical elephant [[Gor (mythology)|Gor]] (the thunderer) or through a [[chameleon]]. Khonvoum created black and white people from black and white clay, and the Pygmies from red clay. For them he also created the jungle with its lush vegetation and animal life.
==See also== * [[Bambuti mythology]]
[[Category:Creator gods]] [[Category:Hunting gods]] [[Category:Sky and weather gods]] [[Category:Pygmy mythology]] [[Category:African mythology]]
{{Africa-myth-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox mountain | name = Rajac | photo = | photo_caption = | elevation_m = 847 | elevation_ref = | map = Serbia | map_caption = Serbia | map_size = 250 | location = Western [[Serbia]] | range = [[Dinaric Alps]] | coordinates = {{coord|44|07|16|N|20|10|54|E|type:mountain_scale:100000|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | type = | first_ascent = | easiest_route = }}
'''Rajac''' is a mountain in western [[Serbia]]. The summit of the mountain lies at {{convert|847|m}}.
The mountain is touristically the best developed and most accessible in the vicinity of [[Belgrade]]. On Rajac the [[battle of Kolubara]] was fought during [[World War I]]. [[Trench]]es dug by the [[Royal Serbian Army|Serbian army]] in November 1914 are still visible.<ref name="nature of serbia">{{cite book|title=NATURE OF SERBIA - Holiday on the move|date=2013|publisher=National Tourism Organisation of Serbia|location=Belgrade|isbn=978-86-6005-295-9|pages=50–51}}</ref>
==Nature== The slopes of the mountain are covered by [[meadow]]s, [[deforestation|clearings]] and [[forest]] of [[Fagus sylvatica|beech]], [[birch]], [[Sorbus aucuparia|ash]], [[Quercus cerris|turkey oak]], [[Pinophyta|conifer]], [[fir]] and [[pine]]. The meadows grow a large number of [[medicinal plants]]. The forests host [[pheasant]], [[roe deer]], [[fox]], [[wild boar]], [[hare]] and [[tortoise]].<ref name="nature of serbia"/>
==Scythe festival== Every year in July there is a 3 day long traditional scythe festival. Main happening is competition in traditional grass cutting with scythe - schyting. In a big field competitors are gathered in traditional folklore clothes where they perform their scything skills and when finished they are rated by jury.It is not only important to be the fastest one but the quality and technique is important to win as well. There is many concerts during this three days and also there is a lot of traditional folklore music in big tents (Šatra) with tables and food, mainly pork or lamb roast , but also sour cabbage is something not to miss. Live music is performed by many artist during this days.
==References== {{reflist}}http://kosidba.com/manifestacije/o-rajcu/
[[Category:Geography of Šumadija and Western Serbia]] [[Category:Mountains of Serbia]]
{{Serbia-stub}}

{{notability|date=February 2017}}
The '''[https://www.na-tsa.org/ North American Taiwan Studies Association (NATSA)]''' is an American 501(c)(3) nonprofit academic organization established in 1994. It is operated by overseas Taiwanese students, North American doctoral students, and recent graduates who are interested in [[Taiwan studies]].<ref name=NATSAWeb>http://www.iias.nl/iiasn/21/institutes/21PP10.html</ref> The NATSA annual conferences are the largest academic events on Taiwan Studies in North America. The NATSA conferences not only provide scholars and students of [[Taiwan]] Studies a regular forum to meet and exchange intellectual ideas, but also allow researchers on East-Asia and beyond to receive dynamic feedback and broaden their academic horizons.
== Early history == When NATSA was founded, it was known as the North American Taiwan Studies Conference and was located on the web at www.natsc.org until August 2006 when it switched to its current address.<ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20060803202034/http://natsc.org/</ref>

==NATSA initiated projects==
=== NATSA Professional Development Webinar Series === The NATSA professional development webinars started in August, 2017. The objectives of the series are:
* Enhance members’ professional skills * Strengthen professional networks of members in the academia and the industry * Promote NATSA to non-members
{| class="wikitable" |+So far, topics of the NATSA professional developmental webinar series included: !Date !Topic !Guest speaker |- |2017/8/12 |Life after PhD— Navigating Assistant Professorship |Dr. Chia-chen Yang (University of Memphis)
Dr. I-chun Catherine Chang (Macalester College) |- |2017/10/1 |Fieldnotes from Academic Job Markets |Dr. John Chung-en Liu (Occidental College) |- |2017/11/4 |Connecting Science to Taiwan: Learning, Organization, and Action |Dr. Ting-chun Kuo (University of British Columbia)

Dr. Adina Zemanek (Jagiellonian University) |- |2018/4/8 |Job Application and Experience in Asia-Pacific Academia |Dr. Harry Wu (Hong Kong University) |}
=== [https://taiwansyllabusprojectnatsa.wordpress.com/ Taiwan Syllabus Project] === NATSA initiative a project in summer of 2017 to identify Taiwan-related courses in the U.S. and Canada. The project is ongoing: https://taiwansyllabusprojectnatsa.wordpress.com/

page.title: Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe

revision.text:
{{distinguish|European Parliament|Assembly of the Western European Union}}
[[Image:PACE logo 75ppi.png|thumb|The emblem of the PACE]] {{Politics of the Council of Europe}} The '''Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe''' ('''PACE''') is the parliamentary arm of the [[Council of Europe]], a 47-nation international organisation dedicated to upholding human rights, democracy and the rule of law. The Council of Europe is an older and wider circle of nations than the 28-member [[European Union]] – it includes, for example, Russia and Turkey among its member states – and oversees the [[European Court of Human Rights]].
The Assembly is made up of 324 members drawn from the national parliaments of the Council of Europe's member states, and generally meets four times a year for week-long plenary sessions in [[Strasbourg]]. It is one of the two statutory bodies of the Council of Europe, along with the [[Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe|Committee of Ministers,]] the executive body representing governments, with which it holds an ongoing dialogue. However, it is the Assembly which is usually regarded as the "motor" of the organisation, holding governments to account on human rights issues, pressing states to maintain democratic standards, proposing fresh ideas and generating the momentum for reform.
The Assembly held its first session in [[Strasbourg]] on 10 August 1949, making it one of the oldest international assemblies in Europe. Among its main achievements are: * ending the death penalty in Europe by requiring new members to stop all executions * making possible, and shaping, the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] * high-profile reports exposing violations of human rights in Council of Europe member states * assisting former Soviet countries to embrace democracy after 1989 * inspiring and helping to shape many progressive new national laws * helping member states to overcome conflict or reach consensus on divisive political or social issues
== Powers ==
{{double image|right|Plenary chamber of the Council of Europe's Palace of Europe 2014 01.JPG|150|Session of the Congress.jpg|150|The [[hemicycle]] of the PACE at the [[Palace of Europe]]}} Unlike the [[European Parliament]] (an institution of the [[European Union]]), the Assembly does not have the power to create binding laws. However, it speaks on behalf of 820 million Europeans and has the power to: * demand action from the 47 Council of Europe governments, who – acting through the organisation's executive body – must jointly reply * probe human rights violations in any of the member states * question Prime Ministers and Heads of State on any subject * send parliamentarians to observe elections and mediate over crises * set the terms on which states may join the Council of Europe, through its power of veto * inspire, propose and help to shape new national laws * request legal evaluations of the laws and constitutions of member states * sanction a member state by recommending its exclusion or suspension Important statutory functions of PACE are the election of the judges of the [[European Court of Human Rights]], the Council of Europe's [[Commissioner for Human Rights]] and its [[Secretary General of the Council of Europe|Secretary General]], as well as the members of the [[Committee for the Prevention of Torture]].
In general the Assembly meets four times per year in [[Strasbourg]] at the [[Palace of Europe]] for week-long plenary sessions. The nine permanent committees of the Assembly meet all year long to prepare reports and draft resolutions in their respective fields of expertise.
The Assembly sets its own agenda, but its debates and reports are primarily focused on the [[Council of Europe]]'s three core statutory aims, defending [[human rights]], promoting [[democracy]] and upholding the [[rule of law]].
===Election of judges to the European Court of Human Rights=== Judges of the [[European Court of Human Rights]] are elected by PACE from a list of three candidates nominated by each member state which has ratified the [[European Convention on Human Rights]]. A 20-member committee made up of parliamentarians with legal experience – meeting [[in camera]] – interviews all candidates for judge on the Court and assesses their CVs before making recommendations to the full Assembly, which elects one judge from each shortlist in a secret vote.<ref>[http://www.assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-EN.asp?newsid=5106&lang=2&cat=8 PACE creates a special committee for the election of judges to the European Court of Human Rights], 24/06/2014.</ref> Judges are elected for a period of nine years and may not be re-elected.
Although the European Convention does not, in itself, require member states to present a multi-sex shortlist of potential appointees, in a 2004 resolution PACE decided that it "will not consider lists of candidates where the list does not include at least one candidate of each sex" unless there are exceptional circumstances .<ref>Adelaide Remiche (August 12, 2012), [http://ohrh.law.ox.ac.uk/election-of-the-new-belgian-judge-to-the-ecthr-an-all-male-short-list-demonstrates-questionable-commitment-to-gender-equality/ Election of the new Belgian Judge to the ECtHR: An all-male short list demonstrates questionable commitment to gender equality] Oxford Human Rights Hub, [[University of Oxford]].</ref> As a result, around one third of the current bench of [http://www.echr.coe.int/Pages/home.aspx?p=court/judges&c=#n1368718271710_pointer 47 judges] are women, making the Court a leader among international courts on gender balance.
== Achievements ==
=== Birthplace of the European Convention on Human Rights === At its very first meeting, in the summer of 1949, the Parliamentary Assembly adopted the essential blueprint of what became the [[European Convention on Human Rights]], selecting which rights should be protected and defining the outline of the judicial mechanism to enforce them. Its detailed proposal, with some changes, was eventually adopted by the [[Council of Europe]]'s ministerial body, and entered into force in 1953. Today, more than sixty years later, the [[European Court of Human Rights]] - given shape and form during the Assembly's historic post-war debates - is regarded as a global standard-bearer for justice, protecting the rights of citizens in 47 European nations and beyond, and paving the way for the gradual convergence of human rights laws and practice across the continent. The Assembly continues to elect the judges of the Court.
=== A helping hand for emerging democracies === Over the decades, the Assembly has been at the forefront of supporting democratic change in successive waves of European nations at key moments in their history, negotiating their entry into the Council of Europe "club of democracies" (as the Assembly has a veto on any new member joining the organisation, it has used this power to negotiate with applicant countries the conditions on which they join). In the 1950s it led the way in embracing recently-defeated Germany, in the 1960s it took a strong stand during the Greek crisis, and in the 1970s it welcomed post-Franco Spain and Portugal into the democratic fold. Above all, it played a key role after the fall of the Iron Curtain in 1989, creating a path towards membership for former Communist countries with its "Special Guest status", paving the way for the historic reconciliation of European nations under one roof.
=== Exposing torture in CIA secret prisons in Europe: the "Marty reports" === In two reports for the Assembly in 2006 and 2007, Swiss Senator and former Prosecutor [[Dick Marty]] revealed convincing evidence [http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-en.asp?newsid=5722&lang=2] that terror suspects were being transported to, held and tortured in CIA-run “secret prisons” on European soil. The evidence in his first report [http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/X2H-Xref-ViewPDF.asp?FileID=11527&lang=en] in 2006 - gathered with the help of investigative journalists and plane-spotters among others - suggested that a number of Council of Europe member states had permitted CIA "rendition flights" across their airspace, enabling the secret transfer of terror suspects without any legal rights. In a second report [http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/XRef/X2H-Xref-ViewPDF.asp?FileID=11555&lang=en] in 2007, Marty showed how two member states - Poland and Romania - had allowed "secret prisons" to be established on their territory, where torture took place. His main conclusions - subsequently confirmed in a series of rulings by the [[European Court of Human Rights]], as well as a comprehensive US Senate report - threw the first real light on a dark chapter in US and European history in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks, kicked off a series of national probes, and helped to make torture on European soil less likely.
== Historic speeches made to PACE == In 2018 an online archive of all speeches made to the Parliamentary Assembly by heads of state or government since its creation in 1949 appeared on the Assembly's website, the fruit of a two-year project entitled [http://www.assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/Speeches/Speech-By-Country-EN.asp "Voices of Europe"]. At the time of its [http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-en.asp?newsid=7112&lang=2 launch], the archive comprised 263 speeches delivered over a 70-year period by some 216 Presidents, Prime Ministers, monarchs and religious leaders from 45 countries - though it continues to expand, as new speeches are added every few months.
Some very early speeches by individuals considered to be "founding fathers" of the European institutions, even if they were not heads of state or government at the time, are also included (such as Sir [[Winston Churchill]] or [[Robert Schuman]]). Addresses by eight monarchs appear in the list (such as King [[Juan Carlos I of Spain]], King [[Albert II of Belgium]] and Grand Duke [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Henri of Luxembourg]]) as well as the speeches given by religious figures (such as [[Pope John Paul II]]) and several leaders from countries in the Middle East and North Africa (such as [[Shimon Peres]], [[Yasser Arafat]], [[Hosni Mubarak]], [[Léopold Sédar Senghor]] or King [[Hussein of Jordan]]).
The full text of the speeches is given in both English and [http://www.assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/Speeches/Speech-By-Country-FR.asp French], regardless of the original language used. The archive is searchable by country, by name, and chronologically.
== Languages == The official languages of the Council of Europe are [[English language|English]] and [[French language|French]], but the Assembly also uses [[German language|German]], [[Italian language|Italian]] and [[Russian language|Russian]] as working languages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailysabah.com/eu-affairs/2015/05/24/turkeys-presence-at-council-of-europe-increased|title=Turkey’s presence at Council of Europe increased|date=24 May 2015|work=DailySabah}}</ref> Each parliamentarian has separate earphones and a desk on which they are able to select the language which they would like to listen to. When foreign guests wish to address the Assembly in languages other than its working languages, they must bring their own interpreters.
== Controversies ==
===Sanctions against the Russian delegation===
In April 2014, after the Russian parliament's backing for the occupation of Crimea and [[2014–16 Russian military intervention in Ukraine|Russian military intervention in Ukraine]], the Assembly decided to suspend the Russian delegation's voting rights as well as the right of Russian members to be represented in the Assembly's leading bodies and to participate in election observation missions. However, the Russian delegation remained members of the Assembly. The sanction applied throughout the remainder of the 2014 session and was renewed for a full year in January 2015, lapsing in January 2016.
In response, the Russian parliamentary delegation suspended its co-operation with PACE in June 2014, and in January 2016 - despite the lapsing of the sanctions - the Russian parliament decided not to submit its delegation's credentials for ratification, effectively leaving its seats empty. It did so again in January 2017 and again in January 2018. Russia's seats remain empty,
The sanctions applied only to Russian parliamentarians in PACE, the Council of Europe's parliamentary body. Russia continues to be a full member of the Council of Europe, and retains full rights in the organisation's other bodies, including its statutory executive body, the [[Committee of Ministers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.europeanvoice.com/article/2014/april/russia-suspended-from-council-of-europe-body/80516.aspx|title=Russia suspended from Council of Europe body|date=10 April 2014|publisher=EuropeanVoice}}</ref>
=== Alleged corruption === In 2013, the ''[[New York Times]]'' reported that “some council members, notably Central Asian states and Russia, have tried to influence the organisation’s parliamentary assembly with lavish gifts and trips”.<ref>Judy Dempsey (February 4, 2013), [https://www.nytimes.com/2013/02/05/world/europe/05iht-letter05.html Corruption Undermining Democracy in Europe] ''[[New York Times]]''.</ref> According to the report, said member states also hire lobbyists to fend off criticism of their human rights records.<ref>Judy Dempsey (April 27, 2012), [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/28/world/europe/28iht-letter28.html Where a Glitzy Pop Contest Takes Priority Over Rights] [[International Herald Tribune]]''.''</ref> German news magazine ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' had earlier revealed details about the strategies of [[Azerbaijan]]’s government to influence the voting behaviour of selected members of the Parliamentary Assembly.<ref>Ralf Neukirch (January 4, 2012), [http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/a-dictator-s-dream-azerbaijan-seeks-to-burnish-image-ahead-of-eurovision-a-806769.html A Dictator's Dream: Azerbaijan Seeks to Burnish Image Ahead of Eurovision] [[Der Spiegel]].</ref>
In January 2017, following a series of critical reports by the [[European Stability Initiative]] (ESI) NGO, and concern expressed by many members of the Assembly, the Assembly's Bureau decided on a three-step response to these allegations, including the setting up of an independent, external investigation body. In May 2017, three distinguished former judges were named to conduct the investigation: Sir [[Nicolas Bratza]], a British former President of the [[European Court of Human Rights]]; [[Jean-Louis Bruguière]], a French former anti-terrorist judge and investigator; and Elisabet Fura, a former Swedish parliamentary Ombudsman and judge on the Strasbourg Court.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-EN.asp?newsid=6663&lang=2&cat=13|title=Allegations of corruption within PACE: appointment of the members of the external investigation body|date=May 30, 2017|website=PACE: News|publisher=Council of Europe|access-date=September 6, 2017|quote=}}</ref> There are no other known examples in recent history of an international organisation setting up an independent, external anti-corruption probe into itself.
The investigation body, which was [http://semantic-pace.net/tools/pdf.aspx?doc=aHR0cDovL2Fzc2VtYmx5LmNvZS5pbnQvbncveG1sL1hSZWYvWDJILURXLWV4dHIuYXNwP2ZpbGVpZD0yMzYxMiZsYW5nPUVO&xsl=aHR0cDovL3NlbWFudGljcGFjZS5uZXQvWHNsdC9QZGYvWFJlZi1XRC1BVC1YTUwyUERGLnhzbA==&xsltparams=ZmlsZWlkPTIzNjEy invited] to carry out its task "in the utmost confidence", appealed for anyone with information relevant to its mandate to [http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-EN.asp?newsid=6792&cat=401 come forward], and held a series of hearings with witnesses. The investigation body's final [http://assembly.coe.int/Communication/IBAC/IBAC-GIAC-Report-EN.pdf report] was published on 22 April 2018 after nine months of work, finding "strong suspicions of corruptive conduct involving members of the Assembly" and naming a number of members and former members as having breached the Assembly's Code of Conduct.
The Assembly responded by declaring, in a [http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-EN.asp?newsid=7053&lang=2 resolution], "zero tolerance for corruption". Following a series of hearings, it sanctioned many of the members or former members mentioned in the Investigative Body's report, either by [http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-en.asp?newsid=7066&lang=2 depriving] them of certain rights, or by [http://assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/News/News-View-en.asp?newsid=7142&lang=2 excluding] them from the Assembly's premises for life. It also undertook a major overhaul of its [http://website-pace.net/en_GB/web/apce/transparency-and-integrity integrity framework] and Code of Conduct.
=== Cultural divisions === Although the Council of Europe is a human rights [[wikt:watchdog|watchdog]] and a guardian against discrimination, it is widely regarded as becoming increasingly divided on moral issues because its membership includes mainly Muslim Turkey as well as East European countries, among them Russia, where social conservatism is strong.<ref name="nytimes.com">Stephen Castle (October 4, 2007), [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/04/world/europe/04iht-schools.4.7755476.html European lawmakers condemn efforts to teach creationism] ''[[International Herald Tribune]]''.</ref> In 2007, this became evident when the Parliamentary Assembly voted on a report compiled by [[Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party|Liberal Democrat]] [[Anne Brasseur]] on the rise of Christian [[creationism]], bolstered by right-wing and populist parties in Eastern Europe.<ref name="nytimes.com" />
== Members == The Assembly has a total of 648 members in total – 324 principal members and 324 substitutes<ref>This number is fixed by article 26.</ref> – who are appointed or elected by the parliaments of each [[Council of Europe#Membership, observers, partners|member state]]. Delegations must reflect the balance in the national parliament, so contain members of both ruling parties and oppositions. The population of each country determines its number of representatives and number of votes. This is in contrast to the Committee of Ministers, the Council of Europe's executive body, where each country has one vote. While not full members, the parliaments of [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Jordan]], [[Morocco]] and [[State of Palestine|Palestine]] hold "Partner for Democracy" status with the Assembly - which allows their delegations to take part in the Assembly's work, but without the right to vote - and there are also observer delegates from the [[Canada|Canadian]], [[Israel]]i and [[Mexico|Mexican]] parliaments.
Some notable former members of PACE include: * former heads of state or government such as Britain's wartime leader Sir [[Winston Churchill]], former German Chancellor [[Helmut Kohl]], former Italian Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]], former Turkish President [[Abdullah Gül]], former Cypriot President [[Glafcos Clerides]], former Finnish President [[Tarja Halonen]], former Georgian President [[Mikhail Saakashvili]], former Albanian President [[Sali Berisha]], and many others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/AssemblyList/MP-Search-Alpha-Archives-EN.asp|title=Members since 1949|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Dick Marty]] ([[Switzerland]]), appointed in late 2005 as [[rapporteur]] to investigate the [[CIA]] [[extraordinary rendition]]s scandal and [[organ theft in Kosovo]] by the [[Kosovo Liberation Army]] from the [[Kosovo war]], in 1998–2001<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wcd.coe.int/wcd/ViewDoc.jsp?Ref=PR968%282010%29&Language=lanEnglish&Ver=original&Site=DC&BackColorInternet=F5CA75&BackColorIntranet=F5CA75&BackColorLogged=A9BACE|title=Council of Europe|work=coe.int|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref> * [[Marcello Dell'Utri]] ([[Italy]]), convicted for complicity in conspiracy with [[the Mafia]] ({{lang-it|concorso in associazione mafiosa}}), a crime for which he was found guilty on appeal and sentenced to 7 years in 2010.<ref name="rep111204">{{cite web|url=http://www.rainews24.rai.it/it/news.php?newsid=142469|title=Rai News: le ultime notizie in tempo reale – news, attualità e aggiornamenti|website=www.rainews24.rai.it}}</ref> * the Scottish soldier, adventurer, writer and MP Sir [[Sir Fitzroy Maclean, 1st Baronet|Fitzroy Maclean]] (United Kingdom), author of the autobiographical memoir and trevelogue ''[[Eastern Approaches]]'', who was a member of PACE on two separate occasions, in [http://www.assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/AssemblyList/MP-Details-EN.asp?MemberID=1559 1972-3 and 1951-2][http://www.assembly.coe.int/nw/xml/AssemblyList/MP-Details-EN.asp?MemberID=1559].
